item.title: [C++]My First Program
item.dc:creator: @pplsuqbawlz pplsuqbawlz
item.description:
@pplsuqbawlz wrote:

[quote=“capndurk, post:1, topic:110594”]i agree, it’s best to think of it this way:

Using system(“PAUSE”) is like burning your furniture for heat when you have a perfectly good thermostat on the wall.[/quote]

Or better yet, none of the above, compile with GCC and then make your own file to call it and pause it, like a batch file… or shell file or something.

Read full topic

item.title: [C++]My First Program
item.dc:creator: @sparkz sparkz
item.description:
@sparkz wrote:

[quote=“capndurk, post:1, topic:109990”][quote author=sparkz link=topic=155485.msg1476786#msg1476786 date=1181704426]
Also Yz85Racer, stop using system calls - they are unneeded, sluggish and are platform dependant.
[/quote]

i think what sparkz means by this is stop using the system() function call, not system calls in general. system calls do make your program platform-dependent (assuming you don’t add support for other operating systems), but they are certainly not unneeded in all cases or sluggish - they’re usually what the standard library functions call on the lower level[/quote]

Yes, that was what I meant

and yes, use cin.ignore() and cin.get(); instead of system(“PAUSE”), and don’t use system(“EXIT”), your main function returns an int for a reason.

Read full topic

item.title: [C++]My First Program
item.dc:creator: @pplsuqbawlz pplsuqbawlz
item.description:
@pplsuqbawlz wrote:

Bojangles!

why not LowerCase(w_string);???
or make your own String class using w_char;

[code]
String::operator+ (String a){
vect<char_w>.append(a.vect);
}

String testcase = String(“Fuck”) + String(“Shit”);[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: [C++]My First Program
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

On another topic

but they are certainly not unneeded in all cases or sluggish - they’re usually what the standard library functions call on the lower level

Yes, actually they really are unneeded and sluggish. On Windows, for example, the system(char *) call translates into something like

CreateProcess(GetEnvironmentVariable("COMSPEC"), strcat("/k", arg), ...)

As for the library functions “making system calls on a lower level”, well I think you have a system call and a call to system confused.

Read full topic

item.title: [C++]My First Program
item.dc:creator: @sparkz sparkz
item.description:
@sparkz wrote:

Javacisnotrecognized:

If you don’t pay attention to problems when you begin programming, later you’ll develop bad habits and be unable to break them.

Because you were bothered about a potential stack overflow in your first C++ program.

Also Yz85Racer, stop using system calls - they are unneeded, sluggish and are platform dependant.

Read full topic

item.title: [C++]My First Program
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Javacisnotrecognized:

His main has 12 bytes of local variables, plus however many the C++ runtime reserves, and 4 more reserved by the CPU to hold the return address.

You have absolutely no idea of knowing how many “bytes of local variables” he has, since he gave no indication of his target. It looks like you’re saying that if you call main() recursively, variables never go out of scope, so eventually you’ll overflow the stack? If so, could you link me to where you read this? I’ve never heard of it before and find it hard to believe, since recursively calling main() is allowed in C (although not in C++ according to google, so I don’t know why his compiler let him do it).[br][size=1]Posted on: June 12, 2007, 10:35:10 AM[/size][hr]Actually, I’m going to eat my words, it probably will crash eventually, but it will be a long ass time. You could thread it, though.

But yeah, much easier just not to do it.

Read full topic

item.title: [C++]My First Program
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

I see… Ohk must remember next time.

Read full topic

item.title: [C++]My First Program
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:10, topic:108628”]It’s not the best design, but I don’t see how it’s going to hurt.

It’s not a stack overflow, either.[/quote]

Yes, it is. His main has 12 bytes of local variables, plus however many the C++ runtime reserves, and 4 more reserved by the CPU to hold the return address.

[quote=“sparkz, post:12, topic:108628”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=155485.msg1467725#msg1467725 date=1181576533]
It’s not the best design, but I don’t see how it’s going to hurt.

It’s not a stack overflow, either.
[/quote]

Yes, it can (although its unlikely) cause a stack overflow. However, considering this is his first program he shouldn’t worry too much about that ;)[/quote]

If you don’t pay attention to problems when you begin programming, later you’ll develop bad habits and be unable to break them.

Read full topic

   if (againchoice == 1)

              system("cls");

Overflow your stack much?

item.title: [C++]My First Program
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:5, topic:108628”][quote author=io9 link=topic=155485.msg1462410#msg1462410 date=1181504082]

  1. C++ is NOT a scripting language
  2. Too many redundant imports
  3. You don’t have to use numbers for R, P, or S, just do something like:
char[200] in = new char[200]; // In case the user types a hunk of shit
cin >> in; // Get user's hunk of shit
if(in == 'R' || in == 'r') { doFukhax(); }

Only that would make it vulnerable to the fact that anything beginning R or r will be rock, but allows more user blah…

Nice job, otherwise

My tribe has spoken
[/quote]

Instead of declaring a 200 character array, reading in a bunch of useless crap and then hoping it’s right, you could just declare a char and read one character…[/quote]

Plus with an array the application is prone to buffer overflows.

Read full topic

3) You don’t have to use numbers for R, P, or S, just do something like:

char[200] in = new char[200]; // In case the user types a hunk of shit
cin >> in; // Get user's hunk of shit
if(in == 'R' || in == 'r') { doFukhax(); }

Only that would make it vulnerable to the fact that anything beginning R or r will be rock, but allows more user blah…

Nice job, otherwise

My tribe has spoken[/quote]

Instead of declaring a 200 character array, reading in a bunch of useless crap and then hoping it’s right, you could just declare a char and read one character…
